newsitem.title: CANADA: Canadian bonds close stronger but underperform.
newsitem.headline: Canadian bonds close stronger but underperform.

text.p: Canadian bonds closed stronger on Wednesday, but underperformed their U.S. counterparts amid a 30-year bond auction and some disappointment that the Bank of Canada did not cut interest rates.

"It was a reasonably quiet day in the market. There was a little bit of disappointment early when the Bank chose not to go," said Mark Chandler, an economist with Goldman Sachs. "The focus in the latter half of the day was the long bond auction.
Canada's 30-year benchmark bond rose C$0.14 to C$110.95 to yield 7.079 percent. The U.S. 30-year benchmark rose 9/32 to yield 6.83 percent.
The spread between the benchmark bonds widened to 25 basis points from an 11-year low of 23 basis points at the close of trading on Tuesday.

Many traders anticipated a rate cut this morning after the release of weak retail sales data on Monday and tame inflation data on Tuesday. While T-bills weakened after the bank failed to move, dealers said expectations of a cut were still helping support shorter term bonds.
New supply also weighed on longer term bonds. The Bank of Canada auctioned C$1.5 billion of Government of Canada bonds with a coupon 8.0 percent and maturing on June 1, 2027.
The auction had an average yield of 7.179 percent and an average price of C$110.104. Traders said the auction was generally well received.
A stronger dollar also helped to provide support for bonds this afternoon, dealers said.
"The currency obviously performed very well today as well and was a contributing factor in our afternoon recovery," said Chandler.
Canada's dollar closed firmer at C$1.3536 (US$0.7443) from Tuesday's close of C$1.3452 (US$0.7434) in active trading, dealers said.
In other prices, the Government of Canada 7.0 percent of 2006 fell C$0.02 to C$104.15 to yield 6.433 percent. The U.S. 10-year benchmark rose 5/32 to yield 6.55 percent.
The negative spread between the 10-year bonds narrowed to 12 basis points from 14 basis points at Tuesday's close.
The three-month cash bill traded at 3.20 percent against the U.S. three-month bill at 5.12 percent.
